match.title: 1st ODI
match.statusText: South Africa won by 10 wickets (with 43 balls remaining)

image.caption: De Beers Diamond Oval - Kimberley
image.longCaption: De Beers Diamond Oval, Home of Griqualand West Cricket  - Kimberley

match.hoursInfo: 10.00 start, First Session 10.00-13.30, Interval 13.30-14.15, Second Session 14.15-17.45

headshotImage.caption: Dwaine Pretorius player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Dwaine Pretorius player page headshot cutout, 2021

dismissalText.commentary: Imrul Kayes c †de Kock b Pretorius 31 (43b 4x4 1x6 62m) SR: 72.09

dismissalComment.html: strangled down leg. Such a poor way to go, even if he hasn't looked anywhere near his best. Short ball, ripe for a nudge to fine leg for a single. He does try just that, but ends up deflecting it straight into de Kock's gloves

headshotImage.caption: Kagiso Rabada player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Kagiso Rabada player page headshot cutout, 2021

headshotImage.caption: Liton Das player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Liton Das player page headshot cutout, 2021

dismissalComment.html: caught at second slip! But confirmation of that will have to come from the third umpire. And it looks like Das will have to go. Outstanding bowling from Rabada. Pitches on a good length. Makes it move away, against the angle and off the pitch. The batsman lunges forward to block with hard hands and looks back to watch Faf du Plessis snapping up a good low catch moving to his right
holes out to the sweeper cover! The ole one-two works out just fine as Rabada bowls it full and wide outside off. Sabbir slices it but doesn't quite put in the power he would like
pulls it straight to midwicket. Short ball, angled into the right-hander, who duly sends the ball straight into the hands of Amla, the only player inside the circle on the leg side

headshotImage.caption: Mohammad Saifuddin  player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Mohammad Saifuddin  player page headshot cutout, 2021

dismissalComment.html: another short ball, this one is top-edged to midwicket and Rabada wraps up with four wickets

headshotImage.caption: Dwaine Pretorius player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Dwaine Pretorius player page headshot cutout, 2021

headshotImage.caption: Imrul Kayes player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Imrul Kayes player page headshot cutout, 2021

dismissalComment.html: strangled down leg. Such a poor way to go, even if he hasn't looked anywhere near his best. Short ball, ripe for a nudge to fine leg for a single. He does try just that, but ends up deflecting it straight into de Kock's gloves

that's gone straight up.... and falls perfectly in Miller's hands. Fine catch, he has to keep his eyes on it against the sun - the shades help with that - has to run back a bit from cover and then take it reverse-cupped before falling over. Big wicket for South Africa, engineered by Pretorius' slower ball. That's all he's cared to bowl in this spell, banging it into the pitch and making batsmen forget about ever trying to hit straight. Mahmudullah tries to make his own pace by running down the track for a flay over cover. Doesn't succeed

dismissalText.commentary: Shakib Al Hasan c Amla b Imran Tahir 29 (45b 2x4 0x6 76m) SR: 64.44

dismissalComment.html: got him! A slip in place and he dangles up a slow, loopy delivery wide of off. Reaches for the drive, doesn't get to the pitch, and it's the googly as well, and it catches the edge through to Amla at slip

dismissalText.commentary: Quinton de Kock not out 168 (145b 21x4 2x6 188m) SR: 115.86
Hashim Amla not out 110 (112b 8x4 0x6 188m) SR: 98.21

headshotImage.caption: Kagiso Rabada player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Kagiso Rabada player page headshot cutout, 2021

headshotImage.caption: Dwaine Pretorius player page headshot cutout, 2021
headshotImage.longCaption: Dwaine Pretorius player page headshot cutout, 2021

commentTextItems.html: length ball on off stump, and he clears his front leg and swipes it away to the left of midwicket. Four more, and South Africa have truly crushed Bangladesh here

commentPostTextItems.html: 5.41pm That's it, then, from Kimberley, where South Africa have gone 1-0 up with an utterly commanding performance. The next stop on this tour is Paarl, on Wednesday. Do join us for that, and keep sending in your comments. Until then, goodbye!

Quinton de Kock is the Player of the Match. "I was quite excited to get back out there. They didn't need me in the Test matches - I was just happy to get back to doing some batting. I think it did differ [between innings]. When we bowled it was quite slow. As the sun started beating, it got a bit flatter, started skidding on a little more. I'm just happy to contribute to the team. Excited to just get out there and bat, let alone score runs or anything else. I think I'm a calming influence on him [when asked if Amla is a calming influence]. It's always good to bat with him, it's a privilege."

Faf du Plessis: "We're playing really well. Another dominating performance - that's what we asked for and they delivered today. We're feeling a little sorry for the Bangladesh bowlers, they've had a hard tour, but that's what being ruthless is about. I thought the pitch was a little slow in the first innings, maybe the heavy roller made it better to bat on in the second innings. It was mostly to do with the wind today - you try and eliminate one side of the field [bowling slower bouncers]. I went to the coach and said, let's do something out of the box, send Andile in at 3, give him a chance to learn to finish the game. [Amla and QdK] were brilliant - they were greedy, and that's what you need to be."

Mashrafe Mortaza: "I think Mushy batted very well, and it was a good effort from the batters. The wicket was good, but we should have tried to bowl more defensively. We always knew it was a good wicket, we knew we had to take wickets, but we couldn't get an early breakthrough. One-day cricket, if you stop runs from both ends, we can put pressure and wickets will come, but we couldn't do that. All credit to Hashim and Quinton. We thought one of our seniors has to bat up the order with Tamim out. Mushy batted really well. We have to keep fighting. It happens in cricket, it happens in all games. I think Tamim should be fit for the next game."

Utkarsh: "This match just confirms what I've wondered about Bangladesh .. outside the subcontinent, who is/are their wicket taking bowlers? Batting is matching the rest of the world standards, bowling is far behind." -- Can't argue with that.

5.24pm Only once before has a side won an ODI by ten wickets while chasing 250 or more. Quinton de Kock and Hashim Amla have bettered the feat achieved by Jason Roy and Alex Hales last year against Sri Lanka, by 26 runs. Bangladesh's attack looked toothless today, and at no point did they look like creating a genuine chance, until they dropped two catches late in the day.

commentTextItems.html: full on off stump, and de Kock finishes with a six, or has he? Opens up at the hips and just hoicks it away over midwicket. This match is over if it's landed on the rope, but replays suggest it may have bounced just inside. It looks like it's yorked the rope
length ball close to off stump, driven to mid-off
slower bouncer, swivels to help it down to long leg

short outside off, and Nasir has dropped a catch at long-on. De Kock smashes it down the ground, a tennis-style forehand drive, and Nasir, jumping at long-on, gets both hands to it over his head, but can't hold on
another yorker, dug out towards extra-cover
yorker close to off stump, jabbed to backward point
full, on the pads, clipped through square leg. Taskin appeals for lbw despite the fact that he middled it, the ball didn't hit his pad at all, and the impact of bat on pad happened outside leg stump
back of a length, down leg, can't connect with the flick

commentPreTextItems.html: Vijay: "Amla involved 7 times in top 10 highest partnerships for any wicket for south Africa shows how important he is for south African team"

commentTextItems.html: bam. Slower ball outside off, back of a length, and de Kock opens up at the hips and flat-bats it over mid-on
back of a length outside off, punched to sweeper cover

back of a length angling down leg. Appeal for a catch down the leg side, not given. Are they reviewing? Nope. Looked for the leg glance, Amla - not sure if it touched anything. Was pretty far from his thigh pad, and it hasn't hit his bat or glove either, Snicko confirms
back of a length close to off stump, punched to mid-off
short outside off, pulled to deep square leg

commentPostTextItems.html: Travis: "Amazing.. not 1 run down to third man for QDK. " -- Oh yeah. Just saw the empty slice on his run-scoring pie!

commentPreTextItems.html: Joel H: "Me again with the same thing as earlier. Amla and de Kock now past the 256 Roy and Hales made last year. If they hang on until 279, it becomes the highest 1st wicket partnership (and team total) in a 10 wicket win in ODIs."

commentTextItems.html: length ball close to off stump, punched down to long-on
full slower ball on off stump, Amla eases a checked drive to sweeper cover
slower ball outside off, dabbed to backward point
slower ball on the pads, clipped into the gap between deep square leg and long leg
back of a length outside off, steered down to third man. Rinse, repeat
short, angling into the front hip, pulled to long leg

dismissalComment.html: another short ball, this one is top-edged to midwicket and Rabada wraps up with four wickets

milestones.description: Hashim Amla and de Kock's 282-run partnership is SA's highest for the 1st wicket in ODIs, breaking the record of 247 between Hashim Amla and Rilee Rossouw
Shakib has scored 41 fifty-plus scores in ODIs, the most for BAN breaking Tamim Iqbal's record
Hashim Amla and de Kock's 282-run partnership is SA's highest for any wicket in ODIs, breaking the record of 256 between David Miller and Duminy
Mortaza has broken the record for playing the most ODIs (178) for BAN, going past Shakib

stories.title: Disappointed Mashrafe wants wickets from his bowlers
stories.subTitle: South Africa v Bangladesh, 1st ODI, Kimberley
stories.seoTitle: Disappointed Mashrafe Mortaza wants wickets from his bowlers
stories.summary: Bangladesh captain Mashrafe Mortaza conceded that while South Africa may have chased down the target of 279 regardless, his team should have picked up at least five to six wickets

image.longCaption: Mashrafe Mortaza gets attention from the physio after damaging his knee brace, Sri Lanka v Bangladesh, 2nd ODI, Dambulla, March 28, 2017

image.caption: Hashim Amla and Quinton de Kock became South Africa's most prolific ODI partnership

stories.title: De Kock, Amla tons power SA to record-breaking win
stories.subTitle: South Africa v Bangladesh, 1st ODI, Kimberley
stories.seoTitle: Quinton de Kock, Hashim Amla tons power South Africa to record-breaking win
stories.summary: Quinton de Kock and Hashim Amla blitzed a century each, became South Africa's most prolific ODI pair of all-time and scripted their biggest win by 10 wickets in ODI history

image.caption: Quinton de Kock scored his 13th ODI hundred
image.longCaption: Quinton de Kock scored his 13th ODI hundred, South Africa v Bangladesh, 1st ODI, Kimberley, October 15, 2017

stories.subTitle: South Africa v Bangladesh, 1st ODI, Kimberley
stories.seoTitle: Mustafizur Rahman ruled out with injury
stories.summary: Mustafizur Rahman suffered an ankle twist during training on Saturday, ruling him out of the first ODI in Kimberley on Sunday
